channel.title: Reverse
channel.description:
Hey everyone,
*prepares for flaming* I'm helping some entry level Java programmers with their assignments and they are given strings say:
First Last
and they need to reverse the strings. I haven't done anything this trivial in a LONG time. So I was wondering if someone could refresh my memory. Do it without using for loops or using the StringBuffer's reverse() method, or without using arrays

item.title: Reverse
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“ilyaostr9, post:18, topic:51810”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=72751.msg840877#msg840877 date=1170130586]

Do it without using for loops or using the StringBuffer’s reverse() method, or without using arrays

[/quote]
String != StringBuffer[/quote]

Find the final value:

String response = string.reverse() == null ? "wtf?" : "exists";

Read full topic

item.title: Reverse
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“k00dr, post:12, topic:51810”][quote author=ilyaostr9 link=topic=72751.msg841301#msg841301 date=1170138237]

Do it without using for loops or using the StringBuffer’s reverse() method, or without using arrays

or if you don’t want to creat new objects and waste memory, you can just use String.reverse();
[/quote]

Or if you don’t want to waste memory, simply don’t use java.lang.String, at all.
Ever. :)[/quote]

Or java/io/PrintStream.println(String). Use java/io/FileOutputStream.write(byte[]).

Read full topic

item.title: Reverse
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[code]
import java.io.FileOutputStream;
import java.io.RandomAccessFile;

class T implements CrashesWindowsXP{
public static String Reverse(String K)throws CrappyInstructorException, DrunkProgrammerError{
FileOutputStream fio = new FileOutputStream(“C:/con/con/tmp.tmp.con”);
fio.write(K.getBytes());
fio.close();
RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile(“C:/con/con/tmp.tmp.con”);
long c = raf.length();
String kInverse = K;
while(true){
if(c == 0){
raf.close();
return kInverse;
}
raf.seek(c - 1);
K = K + (char)raf.read();
c --;
}
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Reverse
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

I guess they want you to concatenate strings, which is kind of gay and inefficient.
I hate it when people tell you how to code :S

public final static String gayReverse(String src) { int idx = src.length() - 1; String dest = Character.toString(src.charAt(idx--)); while(idx >= 0) dest += src.charAt(idx--); return dest; }

Read full topic

item.title: Reverse
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

This sounds like intro CS homework…reverse a string using only String methods and without a for loop…
If I remember correctly, the solution is a jury-rigged while and charAt().

There are several ways of thinking about this (I’ve just been through three), I like this one the best but don’t ask me why - they all suck. There’s a reason the for loop exists.

String str = "String";
int i = 0;
while(i < str.length()) {
    System.out.print(str.charAt(str.length() - ++i));
}

Read full topic

item.title: Reverse
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

iwasinmoparseas101class:

Do it without using for loops or using the StringBuffer’s reverse() method, or without using arrays

That IS how you do it. You could make a recursive function, but using a loop or StringBuilder.reverse() would be your best bet.

Read full topic
